headline: Most of world’s colourful corals go white in record-breaking bleaching | Radio-Canada.ca
context: Bleaching-level heat stress from Jan. 2023 to March 2025 impacted 84% of reefs

annotations.paragraph: Posted: April 23, 2025 8:33 PM

annotations.paragraph: The world's rainbow reefs have gone ghostly white in seas around the globe.
annotations.reason: This provides a vivid description of the current state of the reefs, directly related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: The most intense global coral bleaching event ever has so far struck 84 per cent of the world's reefs and is ongoing, the International Coral Reef Initiative (new window) (ICRI) — a global partnership between nations and non-governmental and international organizations focused on sustainable management of coral reefs — reported on Wednesday.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides essential information about the extent and source of the bleaching event.

annotations.paragraph: The new figure is far worse than previous events that hit 21 to 68 per cent of reefs.
annotations.reason: This offers important context by comparing the current event to past events.

annotations.paragraph: But scientists say the reefs and the corals are not all dead yet and could still bounce back if people take the right steps, including conservation and cutting greenhouse gas emissions.
annotations.reason: This provides relevant commentary on potential recovery and actions needed.

annotations.paragraph: Corals are small marine animals that live in colonies with colourful symbiotic algae that give them their rainbow hues and supply them with most of their food. But when the water gets too warm for too long, the algae release toxic compounds, and the corals expel them, leaving behind a white skeleton — causing bleaching.
annotations.reason: Provides essential context on the process of coral bleaching.

annotations.paragraph: The current global bleaching event, the fourth since 1998, started in January 2023, hitting different parts of the world at different times over the past two years, amid record-breaking ocean temperatures (new window).
annotations.reason: Details the timeline and scope of the current bleaching event.

annotations.paragraph: It was officially declared a global coral bleaching event in April 2024 (new window). Last year, the Earth's hottest on record (new window), the oceans also broke a record (new window), hitting an average annual sea surface temperature of 20.87 C away from the poles.
annotations.reason: Provides specific data on the declaration and temperature records.

annotations.paragraph: The fact that it's ongoing two years later takes the world's reefs into uncharted waters, Britta Schaffelke, a researcher with the Australian Institute of Marine Science and co-ordinator of the Global Coral Reef Monitoring Network, said in a statement accompanying ICRI's news release.

annotations.paragraph: Nicola Smith, an assistant professor of biology at Montreal's Concordia University who also studies coral reefs in the Caribbean, noted that the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has projected that coral reefs will decline 70 to 90 per cent (new window) if the global temperature warms to 1.5 C above pre-industrial temperatures.
